Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing adequate services, resulting in a large
number of youths going to the emergency department.
Investigation On 11/22/24 Complainant reported a concerning number of
youths from Vista Maria were dropped at local hospital emergency
departments within the last 48 hours. There is concern the agency
is not providing proper care and programming to prevent the youth
from needing care in the emergency department.
Interviews:
Chief Administrator, Rights Officer, and Quality Manager were
contacted on 11/22/24 by email to obtain the names of youth that
were seen at a hospital from 11/19/24-11/22/24.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Youth A stated that she would act out when she was bored. Youth
A clarified that she did not attend school in person due to
destructive and self-harming behaviors. Youth A stated she would
cause ‘clears’ all day, every day to make staff and peers mad.
Youth A stated she would start fights with peers and there was
nothing staff could do to stop her. Staff tried to talk to her, got
between the youth, offered other activities, gave space, and
restrained if she were assaulting someone. Police were called
when Youth A was assaulting staff and trying to harm herself.
Youth A was taken to the hospital where staff sat with her for a
while, then she was sent back to the facility. Youth A reported
attending therapy but did not want to. Youth A stated that there
were group activities on the unit, but she often was not able to
attend due to her behavior. Youth A could color/draw and do crafts
at times, until she began to use items as weapons. Youth A stated
she wanted to go outside or on outings and did not understand
2

why her behavior prevented that. A second interview occurred
with Youth A on 1/3/25. Youth A reported she continued to cause
clears and fight with peers because she felt like it. Youth A stated
she was still unable to attend in person school due to assaulting
peers and destroying classrooms. Youth A had a computer to
complete school activities but refused. Youth A was observed to
be staffed at a 2:1 ratio. Youth A stated she continued to attack
staff and peers for no reason. Youth A reported she saw the nurse
on campus for small injuries or illness and went to the emergency
room for suicidal behavior.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Youth B reported she went to the hospital recently due to
attacking staff (This was investigated in SIR 2025SIC0000139).
Youth B was transported to the hospital by police to be checked
for any injuries. Youth B stated that the police were called to
transport youth to the hospital if they were injured, suicidal, or
attacking staff and staff were not able to deescalate the situation.
Youth B stated some staff were helpful and supportive to youth.
Youth B indicated some behaviors caused youth to be placed on
wing restriction, meaning they could not leave the wing for
activities. Youth B reported they participated in school daily,
therapy weekly, and group daily. Youth were also able to
participate in recreational activities through Journey To Success
(JTS) or other groups that came in to do activities. On the unit
youth could also play games, journal, draw, and watch movies.
Youth B did not identify any outdoor activities.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Youth C reported Youth A caused ‘clears’ every single day.
Because of that, many activities were postponed due to staff
addressing Youth A. Youth C reported there were several planned
activities after school that she would like to attend if Youth A was
not causing issues. Youth also played games, talked with peers,
did hair, and had some small group activities. Youth were seen by
the nurse on campus for any minor injuries and only sent to the
hospital if they needed more significant medical care or were
suicidal. Police were called to the unit occasionally if a youth self-
harmed, was suicidal, or non-stop attacking people. Police then
took youth to the emergency room and staff followed.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Youth D reported she felt the staff were supportive and ‘good’
overall. Youth D said there were many activities available to youth
every day. Youth attended school, therapy, group, and had fun
activities available as long as they were not on restriction. Youth D
3

did not have any knowledge about police visiting the facility or
youth going to the hospital.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24
and 1/15/25. Youth E stated staff were calm, helpful, and available
for youth to talk to. Youth E said they attended school and had
therapy 1-2 times per week. The facility offered a lot of activities to
youth such as movies, scheduled events, arts/crafts, games, and
organized group events. However, youth could not participate if
they had been unsafe and were on restrictions. Youth E said other
activities had been offered before, such as outings and cooking,
but they were unable to do that currently due to youth being
unsafe. Youth E stated when peers acted out, staff redirected and
call for assistance from the therapy team if needed. Police had
been called to the facility when youth were harming themselves or
others. Youth were sometimes transported to the hospital by
police, with staff following.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/15/25.
Youth F reported they used to have several organized activities on
the wing, but that decreased due to peer behavior lately. Youth F
stated she wished her peers behavior would not ruin their
opportunities to do fun activities. Recent activities included youth
holiday and birthday celebrations, reading, art, television, therapy,
and some groups. No outdoor activities were identified. If peers
were acting out and physically aggressive to the point that staff
could not calm them, or if youth harmed themselves, police were
called to help. If the police came, they would take the youth to the
hospital with staff following.
Youth G was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/15/24.
Youth G reported youth participated in movie nights, parties,
crafts, cooking, and money management classes. However, they
did not occur as often due to peer behavior causing problems.
Youth also attended school daily and therapy weekly. Youth G
stated police sometimes came to the unit when youth were
assaultive or harming themselves. Police typically took youth to
the hospital to be evaluated, and staff went with them.
Chief Administrator contacted DCWL via email on 12/20/24,
outlining activities planned for youth during their holiday break
from school. Activities included Science Technology Engineering
Math (STEM) activities, basketball, holiday party, Lego activities,
movies, and a content creator workshop.
4

Rights Officer was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/15/25. Rights Officer reported the facility was partnering with
Wayne County Community Mental Health to complete on-site
screenings for Wayne MDHHS youth, to determine if they are in
need of short-term hospitalization. On 1/21/25 Rights Officer
clarified via email that JTS was a program within Vista Maria that
organized events such as groups and dances, where instructors
were brought to campus. Recently they had a hair show and a
family movie day for the youth. Dream Realized through
Education/Empowerment and Mentoring (DREAM) was a group
that was part of JTS that also offers group activities to youth on
campus. Heart Warmers was a spiritual group that youth could
participate in on Sundays. Rights Officer confirmed that all of
these groups remain active on campus.
Quality Manager was contacted via email on 1/23/25 regarding
the plans to revamp services on campus. Quality Manager
reported there was a work group developed by the Activities &
Academic Support Manager. The work group was reviewing
current activities and creating new programming activities to
engage the youth. Previously the facility contracted with outside
partners for activities. There was also a restructured client
advisory board, similar to a student council, to provide youth with
more of a voice in decisions that were made. Youth would be able
to bring any issues, concerns, wishes, requests to the group for
discussion and decision making.
Activities & Academic Support Manager (AASM) was contacted
via email on 1/23/25. AASM outlined the following items available
to youth on campus: afterschool activities include but are not
limited to, expressive therapies such as yoga, dance movement
therapy, music therapy, art therapy, physical activity and
nutritional health education. Academic mentoring and tutoring are
supported through the DREAM program as it connects each youth
with mentors who are successful in their career paths and provide
supports by focusing on their education and future career goals. In
addition, the activity team provides programing that creates a safe
environment to strengthen coping skills, promote social
connections, and support healthy self-esteem and confidence
through creative self-care strategies. Lastly, the Transition to
Independence Process (TIP) model, supports the youth in areas
of education, employment, social skills, relationships and health,
and life skills.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Staff 1 stated activities available to youth included games, books,
5

planned daily activities, and groups. Youth also attended school
and therapy. When youth had physically aggressive behaviors that
made it unsafe for them to participate in group activities, they
would be restricted from activity. When youth were physically
aggressive, staff spoke with them to try to calm them down. Crisis
Prevention Institute (CPI) techniques were also used when youth
were physically aggressive and harming themselves or others. If a
youth had any injuries, they were seen by the nurse or taken to
the hospital if needed. Police were sometimes called to the facility
if youth were assaulting staff, and staff were unable to get them to
stop. Police often took youth to the hospital, rather than to
detention. Staff always accompanied youth to the hospital.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24 and
12/2/24. Staff 2 reported youth had planned group activities every
day. Youth were also able to play games, read and color. Some
youth were not able to participate in activities if they had unsafe
behavior. Some youth caused ‘clears’ off and on all day, which
was disruptive to the daily schedule. Youth caused a lot of
damage and broke things for no reason. Some youth broke doors
or took screws off of wall plates with the intent to swallow them. If
there were any serious incidents of physical altercation, police
were called to assist. Before calling the police, staff would talk to
youth, block, and try to redirect, but that was not always
successful. Managers and the clinical team decided when the
police would be called. Youth were seen by the nurse or taken to
the hospital if they were injured or suicidal. Staff accompanied
youth to the hospital. Staff 2 stated she felt some youth took no
accountability and had no interest in completing the program.
Some youth acted out constantly until they were sent to the
hospital, because that was where they want to be.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Staff 3 reported they were new to the facility and still learning.
Activities for the youth included school, free time, planned group
activities, chores, organized activities by programs on campus,
and free time in which youth could read, draw or watch television.
Youth also attended therapy weekly and had nightly phone calls.
Staff 3 did not have experience with police coming to campus or
youth going to the hospital. However, they indicated it was the
supervisor’s decision when to make those calls.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Staff 4 stated when youth were escalated, staff would talk with
them about the issue and redirect if they were physically acting
out. Physical intervention was only used if youth were injuring
6

themselves or others. A second interview occurred on 12/2/24.
Staff 4 reported that when youth were physically violent, staff
would block and redirect. Some youth had been physically
aggressive, swinging fists at staff, running at staff, taking screws
out of doors and wall plate covers to swallow. Staff intervened to
stop them, but sometimes the supervisors or clinical team would
decide the police needed to be contacted. Police would assist
when youth were very violent and not calming down. Police
generally took youth to the hospital, not jail or detention. Staff
accompany youth to the hospital.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/25/24.
Staff 5 reported being new to the facility and still learning. Staff 5
observed that a “clear” was called on the unit when youth were
escalated, and the situation was unsafe for other youth. Staff
would talk to the youth and try to problem solve and deescalate
the situation. If youth attempted to harm themselves, they were
taken to the hospital for evaluation. If youth assaulted peers or
staff, the police would be called if the supervisors or clinical team
determined it is necessary.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/2/24.
Staff 6 stated youth got aggressive at times. Staff would try to
deescalate, block, redirect, and switch out if needed. If youth were
physically hurting someone, a restraint may be used. Police were
only called if the youth was continuously physically assaulting
people. This decision was made by supervisors. If the police
assisted, they generally took youth to the hospital for an
evaluation. For other, minor incidents, youth were seen on-site by
the nurse. Staff 6 reported that it was difficult to do group activities
when there were frequent behavior issues.
Staff 7 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/2/24.
Staff 7 reported she was involved in several ‘clears’ with Youth A.
Youth A would engage in behavior such as breaking signs to
make weapons, pulling ceiling tiles down, kicking windows, pulling
screws out of the wall, pulling wires out of the ceiling,
yelling/swearing, and attacking staff. Staff would provide multiple
redirections, engage in calm conversation, joke, and distract
youth. Youth A would deescalate briefly, but never fully calm
down. Staff increased supervision and tried to increase activities
to keep youth busy, such as playing games, crafts,
drawing/coloring, watching television, or doing hair. However,
Youth A would continue to act out to elicit reactions from staff. If
staff would not react, Youth A would escalate and attack staff.
Police have been called to assist, after a supervisor gave the
7

approval. Staff would then follow police to the hospital to sit with
youth.
Staff 8 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/3/25. Staff
8 stated when youth act out, staff talk with them, redirect, and try
to get them to focus on something else. If staff were unsuccessful,
they may swap out with another staff or call a supervisor for
assistance. The supervisor may make the decision to call the
police for assistance if a youth was continuously physically
aggressive or harming themselves. Youth may then be taken to
the hospital by police.
Staff 9 was interviewed by phone on 1/16/25. Staff 9 stated youth
participated in daily activities of school, chores, meals, therapy,
crafts, organized group activities, time in the calming room,
watching television, reading and journaling. Some youth chose not
to participate, and others were not able to participate at times due
to unsafe behavior. Police may be called to the unit when a youth
was escalated for an extended amount of time and staff efforts to
calm them did not work. Behaviors such as attacking peers or self-
harm would cause supervisors to give permission for the police to
escort a youth to the hospital to be evaluated. Staff always
followed the police and stayed with youth at the hospital.
Staff 10 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/15/25.
Staff 10 reported youth participated in counseling groups every
afternoon, DREAM programs weekly, Alcoholics Anonymous
weekly for those that need it, games, crafts, coloring, schoolwork,
and other activities that were scheduled on campus. Staff 10
indicated there was not much down time, as youth tend to have
more behavioral issues if they were not busy. Police may be
called to campus when a youth was continuously or seriously
attacking someone and staff could not deescalate, or if a youth
self-harmed or was suicidal. For self-harm and suicidal thoughts
youth typically saw the nurse first, then went to the hospital if
needed. The clinical director would decide when youth should be
seen at the hospital.
Staff 11 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/15/25.
Staff 11 stated youth participate in JTS groups which offered
cooking, music, creative writing, and other activities. However,
attendance had been limited due to youth behavior. When youth
were escalated, staff would talk with them, problem solve and
offer use of the calming room when needed. Police may be called
if youth were attacking people and refusing to stop, or if youth
were injured. Police would then take the youth to the hospital.
8

However, that did not happen as often as before, due to hospitals
refusing to see some youth from the facility. This was due to some
youth acting out over and over with the intention of going to the
hospital to get food and watch television. A crisis team has come
to the facility to complete an assessment to determine if the youth
needed to be hospitalized. This group assessed Youth A recently
and determined she did not need to go. Unfortunately, Youth A
continued to act out and had eight incident reports in four days.
Therapist 1 was interviewed by phone on 1/24/25. Therapist 1
was assigned to Youth A. Therapist 1 stated youth on campus
participated in individual therapy, group work, JTS activities,
DREAM program, Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics
Anonymous, structured activities with volunteer groups,
occupational therapy, religious services, and receive support from
youth counselors. JTS has pro-social life skills, games, yoga,
dance, sports and art. DREAM offers life skills, vocational training,
exercise and mentorship. On the unit, youth participated in art,
games, movies, crafts, activities in the courtyard, and outings in
the community. These activities may be modified at times, due to
youth behavioral or safety issues. Therapist 1 stated youth receive
at least 1 hour of therapy per week, which may be broken up into
smaller sessions, depending on the youth. Therapist 1 reported
Youth A was refusing to attend therapy for a while but has
consistently participated over the last week. Youth A was engaged
and able to talk and process some things. In prior weeks, Youth A
was very escalated and refused to participate. Regarding police or
hospital involvement, Therapist 1 stated police may be called to
campus if youth had violent behaviors and attacked staff or peers.
Police would not be called until after staff made several efforts to
deescalate the youth. A supervisor, clinical director and the
psychiatrist would determine when police would be called to
campus. Generally, this decision was made when a youth needed
to be evaluated, but staff did not feel they could safely transport
the youth. Therapist 1 stated she had some experience with the
new process of having Wayne County Community Mental Health
complete an assessment on-site, in lieu of going to the hospital.
The assessment was well done and determined Youth A needed
inpatient services. However, none of the hospitals would accept
Youth A as they felt her behavior was too significant. Therapist 1
planned to continue looking for an inpatient program for Youth A.
In the meantime, everyone continues to work hard to keep Youth
A and others safe.
Therapist 2 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 2
was assigned to Youth B. Therapist 2 stated they recently began
9

working with this youth as their previous therapist left the facility.
Therapist 2 reported Youth B participated in therapy 1-2 times per
week. Youth B was also offered group therapy, expressive
therapies, recreational therapy through JTS. JTS included Science
Technology Education Math activities, mentoring and educational
tutoring. Youth also received occupational therapy, psychiatric,
medical, and family engagement services. While on their unit
youth were also able to play games, participate in art, watch
television, and participate in groups. Therapist 2 stated Youth B
attended therapy regularly. Although they always engaged,
Therapist 2 was still assessing Youth B as they had only worked
together for a few weeks. Regarding police or hospital
involvement, their services may be needed if a youth was highly
escalated to an extent that it was a safety concern, and they were
unable to regulate themselves or be deescalated. Sometimes
physical intervention could be used, but that was not always safe,
especially with a youth that was self-harming or physically
aggressive. The unit manager, clinical director or head consulting
psychiatrist made the determination if youth should be sent to the
hospital. Therapist 2 stated the facility began working with Wayne
County Community Mental Health (CMH) to complete
assessments at the facility rather than visiting the hospital.
Therapist 2 did not have any experience with this service yet.
Therapist 3 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 3
reported that youth at the facility were offered therapy, psychiatrist
appointments, occupational therapy, DREAM, life skills, leadership
skills, and afterschool activities such as sports, art, and dance.
Youth attended therapy twice per week on a flexible schedule that
worked best for the youth. Regarding police and hospital services,
youth were sent to the hospital when there was a suicide attempt
or AWOL. Youth were also sent if they were highly aggressive
toward others, and staff had been unsuccessful at calming them
down. The police may be called to safely escort youth to the
hospital upon approval by the clinical supervisor and director.
Therapist 3 noted the facility was also working with Wayne County
CMH, as they would come on site to complete assessments for
youth, rather than sending the youth to the hospital.
Therapist 4 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 4
reported youth were offered activities such as games, art, gym,
dance class, and cooking class. Therapist 4 stated youth may feel
that they are not doing as many activities lately, but this is due to
some programs being revamped. Some activities may be
restricted if the youth were physically aggressive. For example,
instead of using colored pencils that may be sharp, a youth could
10

be given crayons to draw. In addition to activities, youth also
attended individual and family therapy, and occupational therapy.
In therapy they worked on triggers and warning signs, coping
skills, thinking/feeling, and discuss problem solving. Regarding
hospitalization and police contact, Therapist 4 reported youth may
be escorted to the hospital by police if they had continued
escalated physical aggression, self-harming, or suicidal behavior
that staff were unable to reduce after multiple attempts to help the
youth self-regulate. The clinical supervisor and clinical director
must make the determination if assistance is to be called.
Therapist 4 also reported the facility began a partnership with
Wayne County CMH, where CMH staff would complete on-site
assessments to determine if a youth was eligible for short term
hospitalization.
Documents Reviewed:
• Vista Maria Program Statement updated 3/22/2024: Direct
Program Services: “weekly individual therapy, monthly
family and group therapy, sensory integration approaches,
expressive therapies, group counseling focused on
intervention, non-violent crisis interventions approaches,
community outings, daily recreation, after-school activities,
nursing services, mentoring, life skills education, family
visitation and phone call opportunities, transportation to
home visits when appropriate, family engagement events,
and aftercare services for six months after discharge.
Contracted services include on-campus education,
psychiatric and psychological evaluations, medical, optical,
and dental examinations.”
• “Youth log of daily expectations”: Staff must indicate if
youth met expected behavior standards for the following
activities: social skills, peer interaction, school/study time,
personal care, group participation, recreation participation,
room care/chores, healthy eating, appropriate dress,
effective coping skills, safe behavior/transport.
• ‘Emergency Psychiatric Care” policy dated July 2014.
• If client is in imminent danger of harming herself or
others, supervisor/team leader/staff contacts 911.
• If the situation is serious but there is no imminent
danger, arrange for staff or private ambulance
transport to appropriate psychiatric crisis
assessment center.
• Staff should not transport an uncontrollable client. If
the situation requires it, the supervisor should call
911 for assistance.
• “Police on Campus” policy dated March 2021:
11

• When a situation arises that threatens the health,
safety, and welfare of our clients or staff and that is
beyond our ability to control, the police department
should be contacted for assistance.
• The shift supervisor or designated will contact the
police via 911.
• Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that had
schedule activities documented such as daily group, daily
phone calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS, “Chicktime”
with volunteer group, Vista Maria reads (Book Ladies), Lost
Voices Concert, town hall meeting, Boots & Bites with Lace
Up Detroit, Pet Therapy, holiday events with Abhi Shah
Foundation, holiday decorating, and youth health fair.
However, there was no documentation available regarding
youth participating in any outdoor activities.
• A review of MiSACWIS incident reports for the facility was
completed to confirm the youth that visited the hospital from
11/19/24-11/22-24: Youth A, Youth B and Youth C.
• Case file review for Youth A:
• Placement at the facility on 11/1/24-11/27/24,
Emergency Room from 11/27/24-11/28/24, inpatient
hospital from 11/28/24-12/6/24, returned to facility on
12/6/24.
• Incident report dated 11/17/24 IR- Youth A climbed on
kitchen counter because she was bored. Staff told youth
to get down off the counter and she did. Youth sat on
counter, trying to break paper towel dispenser. Then
stood and removed shield from light fixture. Staff tried to
grab it from her, youth took shield in hallway, stomped
on it and broke it to pieces. Staff called for supervisor.
Supervisor arrived, youth put pieces of broken light
shield in her mouth and bra. Staff tried to talk with her to
get pieces away. Youth began kicking door. Staff
blocked her to avoid hurting herself. Youth started trying
to take light socket apart. Clinical supervisor called.
Police arrived and took youth to ER. Youth had x-ray,
no items were found, youth was discharged but tried to
truant from hospital while staff were there. Police
returned to hospital and assisted with transport back to
facility.
12

• Hospital discharge dated 11/17/2024. Reported Youth A
swallowed foreign body- screw and drywall. X-ray
showed no foreign bodies.
• Updated Service Plans 12/9/24- Youth A has a
supportive family and is able to attend to her basic
needs. Youth A has aggressive behavior and acts out
physically with staff. Youth A desires to live with her
mother.
• Therapist 1 provided documentation verifying that Youth
A was consistently offered weekly therapy. While Youth
A attended most sessions, there were some weeks that
Youth A initially refused a session, then spoke with
Therapist 1 later in the week.
Case file review for Youth B:
• Youth B hospitalized from 2/28/24-8/8/24, placed at
Vista Maria on 8/8/24.
• Incident report dated 11/21/24- Youth B became
agitated, went into the bathroom and stood on the sink
to reach a light fixture. Staff blocked and encouraged
Youth B to get down. Youth B sat on the floor for a few
minutes, then went into her room. Staff removed Youth
B’s bedding as a safety precaution and placed her on
suicidal observation. Youth B broke a brush into small
pieces and put it in her mouth. Additional staff were
called to assist while staff tried to verbally de-escalate
youth. Youth B crawled under her desk and hid objects
in her bra. Youth B was hiding her arms but appeared
to be attempting to self-harm. Police were called as
Youth B continued to be non-compliant. Police arrived
and had to physically remove Youth B from under the
desk. Blood was observed on Youth B’s arm, police
cuffed and searched Youth B. Police transported Youth
B to the hospital. Youth B refused care at the hospital,
attempted to AWOL, and was returned to the facility.
• Incident report dated 11/21/24- Youth B was improperly
restrained after punching staff. Youth B went to the
hospital for evaluation after. (SIR 2025SIC0000139).
• Incident report dated 11/22/24- Youth B went into her
bedroom and wrapped a sheet around her neck. Staff
13

removed the sheet. Youth B was responsive. Nurse
went to the unit to evaluate. Youth B refused to speak

Rule Code Recreational activities, equipment, and supplies; swimming
Title restriction.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4136
Section (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor and outdoor
Description recreational activities designed to meet the residents’ needs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing sufficient activities for youth.
Investigation During interviews, youth and staff reported there were several
activities available to youth in the program. However, Youth A,
Youth C, Youth E, Youth F, Youth G, Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 6,
and Staff 11 reported that activities did not always occur. Youth
and staff indicated there was increased acting out behavior when
activities did not occur, or when youth were placed on wing
restriction from activities. Youth and staff reported concerns that
the agency’s behavior management/reward system was not
effective. Youth and staff reported concerns that staff spend too
much time deescalating certain youth and therefore not
completing activities with other youth.
During interviews Youth A, Youth B, Youth E and Youth F
reported a lack of outdoor activities available to all youth.
Activities & Academic Support Manager provided
documentation of several indoor activities made available for
youth. However, no outdoor activities were identified.
During a call on 2/6/25, Chief Administrator and Quality
Manager reported that youth participate in outdoor activity when
the weather permits. However, they were unsure if there was a
15

schedule of outdoor activities. They were asked to provide
documentation to show that youth were participating in outdoor
activity on a regular basis. In subsequent emails on 2/10/25 and
2/14/25, Quality Manager reported they did not have any
documentation to verify this request.
Documents Reviewed:
Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that had
schedule activities documented such as daily group, daily phone
calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS, “Chicktime” with volunteer
group, Vista Maria reads (Book Ladies), Lost Voices Concert,
town hall meeting, Boots & Bites with Lace Up Detroit, Pet
Therapy, holiday events with Abhi Shah Foundation, holiday
decorating, and youth health fair.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as youth reported being
unable to participate in activities due to peer behavior, or not
having any activities available to them while on wing restriction.
Youth also reported they are not able to engage in outdoor activity
and the agency did not have any documentation to verify outdoor
activities occur with youth.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was offered regarding youth behavior on units that
disrupt the daily activities. When disruptive behavior is ongoing
and prohibiting other youth from their daily activities, efforts should
be made to continue activities with youth in another area, away
from the disruption. Not only would this be a positive step for the
other youth, but it would also take away the acting out youth’s
power to control the daily activity of the unit. Additionally, for youth
placed on restriction that are missing activities, staff should
continue to focus on encouraging the youth to reduce behaviors in
order to re-join the group. This may help alleviate the youth’s
feeling that wing restriction is never ending. Lastly, inclusion of
some restricted youth ideas in the client advisory board would be
a great way to determine some activities that restricted youth may
be interested in, to help them increase engagement in the
program.
Conclusion Violation Established
